title: Welcome to Exolane
text: Welcome to Exolane Trade with Confidence Exolane is a non-custodial leveraged trading protocol built on Arbitrum One. We're designed for traders who value **predictable costs**, **transparent risk**, and **on-chain enforceable rules**. Why Exolane? Get Started Key Features **Markets** 10 live perpetual markets â€” BTC, ETH, SOL, BNB, XRP, DOGE, XMR, AVAX, L
headings: Welcome to Exolane Trade with Confidence Why Exolane? Get Started Key Features Quick Links

title: What is Exolane?
text: What is Exolane? Exolane is a **non-custodial leveraged trading protocol** built exclusively on Arbitrum One. It enables traders to take long or short leveraged positions using USDC collateral, while enforcing predictable rules that protect against extreme market conditions. The Problem We Solve Traditional perpetual exchanges suffer from several issues: **Unpredictable funding rates** Funding can spike to 100%+ APR during volatile periods, draining positions **Hidden fees** Complex fee structur
headings: What is Exolane? The Problem We Solve How Exolane is Different 1. Capped Funding Rates 2. Truly Non-Custodial 3. Transparent & Minimal Fees 4. Deterministic Liquidations How It Works Supported Markets Network Next Steps

title: Closing Positions
text: Closing Positions This guide covers how to close positions and understand the settlement process. Closing a Full Position To completely exit a position: Steps: Find your position in the positions panel Click "Close Position" or "Close" Review the estimated PnL Confirm the transaction What happens: Your position size is set to 0 PnL is calculated at the settlement price PnL is added to (or subtracted from) your collateral Collateral is freed for withdrawal or new trades Closing a Partial Position

title: Collateral & Margin
text: Collateral & Margin This guide explains how collateral and margin work on Exolane. Key Concepts **Collateral** USDC deposited into your Exolane account **Margin** Collateral allocated to a specific position **Free Collateral** Collateral not currently used by positions **Initial Margin** Minimum margin required to open a position **Maintenance Margin** Minimum margin required to keep a position open Collateral Account Exolane uses a **unified collateral account** system: â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€

title: Leverage
text: Leverage Leverage allows you to control larger positions with less capital. This guide explains how leverage works on Exolane. What is Leverage? Leverage is a **multiplier** on your position: Leverage = Position Value / Collateral Example: Position: $10,000 worth of BTC Collateral: $1,000 Leverage: $10,000 / $1,000 = 10x With 10x leverage: A 1% price move = 10% gain/loss on your collateral A 10% price move = 100% gain/loss on your collateral How Exolane Handles Leverage Unlike some exchanges whe
headings: Leverage What is Leverage? Example: How Exolane Handles Leverage Benefits: Leverage Calculation Interactive Examples: Maximum Leverage Leverage and Risk 10x Long Position on BTC Comparison at Different Leverage Levels Leverage and Liquidation Example: $100,000 BTC Long Adjusting Leverage To Decrease Leverage (Safer): To Increase Leverage (Riskier): Example: Dynamic Leverage Long Position Example: Leverage Best Practices For Beginners: For Experienced Traders: Risk Management Rules: Leverage Comparison Common Mistakes âŒ Using Maximum Leverage âŒ Ignoring Dynamic Leverage âŒ No Stop-Loss at High Leverage âŒ Overleveraging Total Account Summary Next Steps

title: Order Types
text: Order Types Exolane supports various order types to give you control over your entries and exits. Market Orders Execute immediately at the current oracle price. When to Use: You want immediate execution Speed is more important than exact price High-confidence directional moves How It Works: Submit order Wait for oracle update (seconds) Order fills at oracle price Example: BTC showing: $100,000 You submit: Buy 0.1 BTC market order Oracle updates: $100,050 You receive: 0.1 BTC at $100,050 Limit Or

title: Funding Rates
text: Funding Rates Funding rates are periodic payments between long and short traders. Exolane's funding system is designed to be **predictable and capped**. What is Funding? Funding is a mechanism that: Balances long and short positions in the market Anchors perpetual prices to spot prices Transfers value between traders (not to the protocol) How Funding Works The Basic Mechanism When more traders are LONG: â†’ Longs pay Shorts â†’ Incentivizes shorts, discourages longs â†’ Brings balance When more trader
headings: Funding Rates What is Funding? How Funding Works The Basic Mechanism Payment Direction Exolane's Funding Cap The Hard Cap: Â±15% Per Year Why Cap Funding? Real-World Comparison Funding Rate Calculation The Formula Example: Funding Payment Calculation For Your Position Example: Annualized Perspective: Funding Accrual Continuous vs. Periodic When Funding is Applied Checking Current Funding Funding Rate History Strategies Around Funding Earning Funding (Receiving) Minimizing Funding Costs Funding vs. Other Exchanges Key Takeaways Next Steps

title: Fee Structure
text: Fee Structure Exolane is designed to have **minimal and transparent fees**. This page explains every fee you may encounter. Fee Summary Taker Fee 0.02% Opening/closing positions Maker Fee 0.00% N/A Liquidation Fee 0.00% If liquidated Withdrawal Fee 0.00% Withdrawing USDC Funding Variable (capped Â±15% APR) While holding position Trading Fees Taker Fee: 0.02% Applied when you open or close a position. Fee = Position Notional Value Ã— 0.02% Examples: $1,000 $0.20 $10,000 $2.00 $100,000 $20.00 Maker
headings: Fee Structure Fee Summary Trading Fees Taker Fee: 0.02% Examples: Maker Fee: 0.00% Fee Calculation Examples Opening a Long Position Closing a Position Round Trip (Open + Close) Liquidation Fees Liquidation Penalty: 0% What Happens at Liquidation: Why No Penalty? Gas Costs Funding (Not a Fee) No Hidden Fees Fee Comparison vs. Centralized Exchanges vs. Decentralized Exchanges True Cost of Trading Short-Term Trade (1 day) Medium-Term Trade (1 week) Long-Term Trade (1 month) Optimizing Costs 1. Use Appropriate Leverage 2. Trade Larger Sizes (If Comfortable) 3. Watch Funding Direction 4. Use Limit Orders Strategically 5. Batch Operations Where Do Fees Go? Summary Next Steps

title: Liquidations
text: Liquidations Liquidations are a necessary mechanism to maintain protocol solvency. Exolane's liquidation system is designed to be **fair and non-punitive**. What is Liquidation? Liquidation occurs when a position's margin falls below the **maintenance margin requirement**. The position is forcibly closed to prevent losses from exceeding collateral. If: Effective Margin < Maintenance Margin Then: Position can be liquidated Key Features of Exolane Liquidations âœ… No Liquidation Penalty Unlike most
headings: Liquidations What is Liquidation? Key Features of Exolane Liquidations âœ… No Liquidation Penalty âœ… Remaining Collateral Returns to You âœ… Only Gas Costs Reimbursed When Does Liquidation Occur? Margin Health Formula Effective Margin Calculation Example: Liquidation Price For Long Positions: For Short Positions: Approximate Formula (Long): Example: Liquidation Process Step 1: Margin Falls Below Requirement Step 2: Position Becomes Liquidatable Step 3: Keeper Triggers Liquidation Step 4: Settlement What Happens to Your Funds? If Collateral Remains: If Position Goes Underwater: Avoiding Liquidation 1. Use Lower Leverage 2. Set Stop-Losses 3. Add Margin 4. Reduce Position Size 5. Monitor Margin Health Liquidation vs. Stop-Loss Margin Health Indicators Oracle Protection After Liquidation Liquidation FAQ Q: Why was I liquidated even though price recovered? Q: Why is there no liquidation penalty? Q: Can I avoid liquidation by paying more gas? Q: Is there partial liquidation? Summary Next Steps

title: Oracle System
text: Oracle System Exolane uses oracles to provide fair, manipulation-resistant price feeds for all trading activity. Overview All prices on Exolane come from **Pyth Network**, a high-fidelity oracle designed for DeFi. **Provider** Pyth Network **Update Frequency** Sub-second **Staleness Threshold** 60 seconds **Data Sources** Major exchanges, market makers Why Pyth Network? Speed Updates every ~400ms Critical for trading accuracy Reflects real-time market conditions Accuracy Aggregates from 50+ data
headings: Oracle System Overview Why Pyth Network? Speed Accuracy Decentralization How Prices Are Used Position Valuation Margin Calculation Order Execution Liquidation Oracle Freshness Staleness Window: 60 Seconds Why This Matters: Oracle Update Flow Price Display vs. Settlement What You See: What You Get: Why the Difference? Example: Available Price Feeds Oracle Security Multiple Publishers Confidence Intervals Timestamp Validation On-Chain Verification Edge Cases Oracle Downtime Price Spikes Flash Crashes Oracle Fees Transparency Oracle FAQ Q: Can the team manipulate prices? Q: What if Pyth goes down? Q: Why didn't I get the price I saw? Q: Are prices the same as Binance/Coinbase? Q: What's the maximum price lag? Summary Next Steps

title: Settlement
text: Settlement Settlement is the process by which orders are executed and positions are updated. Exolane uses **oracle-based settlement** for fair execution. What is Settlement? Settlement is when your order is **executed** and your position is **created or modified**: Order Submitted â†’ Pending â†’ Oracle Update â†’ Settlement â†’ Position Active Settlement Flow Step-by-Step: 1. USER SUBMITS ORDER â””â”€â”€ Transaction sent to Arbitrum 2. ORDER ENTERS PENDING STATE â””â”€â”€ Waiting for oracle price 3. ORACLE UPDATES
headings: Settlement What is Settlement? Settlement Flow Step-by-Step: Timeline: Why Oracle-Based Settlement? The Problem with Instant Execution: Exolane's Solution: Benefits of Oracle Settlement Settlement Price What Determines Your Price? You Cannot Control: You Can Control: Pending State Pending Limits: Settlement Timing Oracle Granularity Current Settings: Order Types and Settlement Market Orders Limit Orders Stop-Loss / Take-Profit What Can Delay Settlement? Stale Oracle Network Congestion Pending Limit Hit After Settlement Checking Settlement Status Order States: In the UI: Settlement Fees Edge Cases Price Moves While Pending Multiple Orders Same Settlement Order Cancelled During Pending Settlement vs. Other Exchanges FAQ Q: Why didn't I get the price I saw? Q: How long do I wait for settlement? Q: Can I speed up settlement? Q: What if oracle never updates? Q: Is there slippage protection? Summary Next Steps

title: Risk Disclosure
text: Risk Disclosure Overview Before using Exolane, you must understand and accept the following risks. This is not an exhaustive list, and other risks may exist. Trading Risks Leverage Risk Leverage amplifies both gains AND losses. 1x 10% loss 5x 50% loss 10x 100% loss (liquidation) 20x Liquidation at 5% move **Your entire collateral can be lost** if the market moves against your position. Liquidation Risk If your position's margin falls below maintenance requirements: Your position will be forcibly

Use Appropriate Leverage 2. Always Use Stop-Losses 3. Size Positions Appropriately 4. Secure Your Wallet 5. Monitor Positions 6. Understand Before Trading Eligibility Acknowledgment Questions?

title: FAQ
text: FAQ Answers to commonly asked questions about Exolane. General Questions What is Exolane? Exolane is a non-custodial leveraged trading protocol on Arbitrum One. It allows you to trade perpetual futures with up to 20x leverage using USDC as collateral. Why is it called "non-custodial"? Non-custodial means Exolane never takes custody of your funds. Your collateral is held in smart contracts that only you control. There are no admin keys that can access your money. What network does Exolane run on?
headings: FAQ General Questions What is Exolane? Why is it called "non-custodial"? What network does Exolane run on? What markets can I trade? Trading Questions What's the maximum leverage? What are the trading fees? Why is funding capped at 15%? Does Exolane profit from funding? Why didn't my order execute at the price I saw? Why is there a delay in my order? Account Questions How do I deposit funds? Can I withdraw anytime? What is 1-Click Trading? Is there a minimum deposit? Risk Questions Can I lose more than I deposit? What happens if I get liquidated? Why was I liquidated even though the price recovered? How can I avoid liquidation? Technical Questions Where do prices come from? What if the oracle goes down? Are the contracts audited? Is the code open source? Troubleshooting My transaction is stuck I can't open a position My balance seems wrong The app won't connect to my wallet Still Have Questions? Next Steps

title: Glossary
text: Glossary A comprehensive list of terms used throughout Exolane and DeFi perpetuals trading. A Arbitrum One A Layer 2 scaling solution for Ethereum that provides fast, cheap transactions while inheriting Ethereum's security. C Collateral Assets (USDC on Exolane) deposited as backing for leveraged positions. Your collateral determines your maximum exposure and absorbs losses. Collateral Account Your unified account on Exolane where deposited USDC is held. Collateral can be allocated to multiple po
headings: Glossary A Arbitrum One C Collateral Collateral Account D DSU (ExoUnit) E Effective Margin Entry Price F Funding Rate Funding Cap I Initial Margin L Leverage Limit Order Liquidation Liquidation Price Long Position M Maintenance Margin Maker Margin Margin Health Margin Ratio Mark Price Market Order N Non-Custodial Notional Value O Open Interest Oracle Oracle Settlement P Pending Order Perpetual (Perp) PnL (Profit and Loss) Position Pyth Network R Realized PnL S Settlement Short Position Slippage Staleness Stop-Loss T Take-Profit Taker Timelock U Unrealized PnL USDC V Vault W Wallet 1-9 1-Click Trading Next Steps
